title: National Health Insurance Scheme
summary: Ghana launched Africa's most ambitious premium-based national health insurance scheme in 2003, eventually claiming 40% active membership. While the scheme expanded access and introduced free maternal care, it has struggled with financial sustainability, low active enrollment, and quality of care concerns.

content:
## Background

Ghana's health financing system in the 1990s was characterized by a "cash-and-carry" policy requiring patients to pay out-of-pocket at the point of service. Introduced as part of structural adjustment reforms in the 1980s, user fees proved devastating for health access among the poor. Studies documented that significant proportions of the population—particularly in rural areas—were forgoing needed care due to inability to pay. Maternal mortality remained high, and preventable childhood diseases continued to claim lives that timely treatment could have saved.

Community-based health insurance (CBHI) schemes emerged organically in several districts during the 1990s, notably in the Nkoranza and Damongo districts, demonstrating local demand for prepayment mechanisms. These schemes, while small, showed that Ghanaians were willing to pay premiums to avoid catastrophic health payments. The National Democratic Congress (NDC) government explored national health insurance options in the late 1990s, but it was the New Patriotic Party (NPP), elected in 2000 under President John Kufuor, that made NHIS a flagship policy commitment.

The broader context included a growing international consensus around universal health coverage and social health protection. Ghana's decision to pursue a premium-based social health insurance model, rather than a purely tax-financed system, reflected both fiscal constraints and the influence of the community-based insurance experience. The scheme also drew on comparative lessons from countries including South Korea, Thailand, and Colombia.

## The Intervention

The National Health Insurance Act (Act 650) was passed in 2003, and the scheme became operational in 2005 under the National Health Insurance Authority (NHIA). The design created a decentralized structure of District Mutual Health Insurance Schemes (DMHIS), each operating as a nominally independent entity but regulated and subsidized by the NHIA. Every Ghanaian was required to register, though enforcement of the mandate was weak.

Funding came from three main sources: a 2.5% National Health Insurance Levy added to the Value Added Tax; a 2.5% deduction from Social Security and National Insurance Trust (SSNIT) formal sector contributions; and individual premiums ranging from GHS 7.2 to GHS 48 per year (approximately $2-$12), income-adjusted. Crucially, several categories were exempt from premium payments: children under 18 with registered parents, persons over 70, SSNIT contributors, SSNIT pensioners, and pregnant women (added in 2008). An indigent exemption was designed for the extreme poor, though its implementation was problematic.

The benefit package was generous by regional standards, covering about 95% of the disease burden in Ghana including outpatient consultations, inpatient care, maternity services, dental care, eye care, and prescription medicines on a defined formulary. Providers were reimbursed through a Ghana Diagnosis Related Groupings (G-DRG) system for services and fee-for-service for medicines. In 2008, the government introduced a free maternal care policy under the NHIS, automatically enrolling all pregnant women and covering all pregnancy and delivery-related costs.

## Results & Evidence

The NHIS achieved significant expansion of coverage in its early years. By 2010, the scheme reported over 8 million active members (approximately 33% of the population), and registered membership continued to grow. The free maternal care policy had particularly visible effects: institutional delivery rates increased from 45% in 2007 to 73% by 2014 according to Demographic and Health Survey data, and there is evidence that the policy contributed to maternal mortality reduction.

Blanchet, Fink, and Osei-Akoto (2012), in a study published in *Social Science & Medicine*, used propensity score matching to evaluate the NHIS's impact on healthcare utilization and out-of-pocket spending. They found that NHIS membership significantly increased outpatient and inpatient utilization and reduced out-of-pocket expenditure, with the strongest effects among the poorest quintile. Agyepong and Adjei (2008), in *Health Policy and Planning*, provided an early and influential analysis of the implementation process, documenting both achievements and the gap between policy design and ground-level reality.

Asenso-Okyere et al. and other researchers documented improvements in health-seeking behavior, with insured individuals significantly more likely to seek formal care and less likely to self-medicate. The scheme also contributed to the formalization of the health provider market, as facilities sought NHIA accreditation to access insured patients.

## Challenges & Criticisms

Financial sustainability has been the scheme's most persistent challenge. The generous benefit package, combined with expanding exempt categories (who constituted the majority of members but contributed no premiums), created a structural funding gap. By 2014, the NHIA owed providers over GHS 600 million in unpaid claims; by 2018 this had grown to over GHS 1.2 billion. Provider reimbursement delays of 6-12 months became routine, causing many providers to demand cash payments from insured patients, effectively undermining the insurance promise.

Actual active membership was consistently lower than official figures suggested. Witter and Garshong (2009) and subsequent analyses showed that while many Ghanaians registered for NHIS, a substantial proportion—perhaps 30-40%—allowed their membership to lapse and were not actively covered. The indigent exemption, intended to cover the extreme poor, reached only a fraction of eligible individuals due to cumbersome identification processes and inadequate funding. Oxfam (2013) documented that the poorest Ghanaians were the least likely to be NHIS members despite the exemption policy.

Quality of care concerns also emerged. Long waiting times at NHIS-accredited facilities, drug stockouts, and provider reluctance to see insured patients (due to reimbursement delays) were commonly reported. The G-DRG reimbursement rates were considered too low by many providers, incentivizing them to provide minimal care to insured patients while charging higher fees to uninsured paying patients.

## Key Lessons

- **Premium-based insurance in low-income settings faces inherent revenue limitations**: When the majority of the population is informal sector workers or subsistence farmers, premium collection is difficult and expensive, and the fiscal base is necessarily narrow.
- **Generous benefit packages must be matched by adequate financing**: Ghana's mismatch between a broad benefit package and limited revenue created chronic provider payment delays that undermined the scheme's credibility.
- **Free maternal care through insurance can increase institutional deliveries**: The 2008 policy demonstrated that removing financial barriers to maternity care can produce rapid and significant increases in facility-based births.
- **Indigent exemption policies require proactive identification and enrollment**: Waiting for the poorest to self-identify and register does not work; active outreach and simplified enrollment processes are necessary.
- **Provider payment systems shape the quality of care**: Reimbursement rates, timeliness of payment, and the design of provider payment mechanisms directly affect whether insured patients actually receive quality services.
